div.h3: POSTPONED: School Budget Vote and Trustee Election
div.div: POSTPONED - Due to Executive Order No 202.13 the NYS School Budget Vote and Election has been postponed. As soon as we receive more guidance from the Governor's Office we will update the community.

They include important prevention and symptoms information. Click here to view the information.

div.div: In light of recent concerns related to the 2019 Novel (new) Coronavirus (2019-nCoV), the district has created a webpage to share messaging, as well as resources and information provided by the New York State Department of Health and the New York State Department of Education. They include important prevention and symptoms information. Click here to view the information.

div.p:
Prior to the closing of schools, the fifth graders at Tackan Elementary School learned teambuilding and technology skills during their Project Lead the Way lessons. Using Vex kits and working in small groups, students built a test bed for their robots during a unit on robotics and automation. The students learned through research about robotics and how the world is helped by robots. They were preparing to build their own simple robots by sorting and pulling parts for the test beds.
Click Here to View

A High School West student enlisted the help of her friends to spread kindness and smiles to frontline workers and the community during this pandemic.
Grace Kamvakis, a junior at High School West, and her mom Heidi, decided to paint rocks with inspirational thoughts on them, and leave them at the local hospitals. Grace enlisted some friends at High School West to help: Caitlin Camilleri, Olivia Bove, Goeun Chang, Carissa Philips and Jenna and Julia Savino.
After collecting and sealing... Click Here to View

Thanks to a project done in a middle school technology class by her daughter, a physical therapist who works in Smithtown Elementary School is able to share the power of learning with her own students.
Before the closing of schools, students in Mr. Kellys technology class at Great Hollow Middle School are assigned a project to create and build a toy for a child with special needs. Avery Nasta built a puzzle that her mom, Kathleen, now uses with her elementary students. The puzzle... Click Here to View

img.title: Building Next Level Literacy Skills at Dogwood

h3.a: Building Next Level Literacy Skills at Dogwood

div.p: Before the schools shut down, the fifth graders at Dogwood Elementary School were busy building their literacy skills in March. The students crafted two voice poems creating a dialogue between two main characters and depicting their relationship based on the book Esperanza Rising. Students also read Malalas Magic Pencil as a class and wrote about her identity, personality and her efforts to become the youngest person to win the Nobel Peace... Click Here to View

We are starting an exciting project that will be part of the district's history for years to come. All students are welcome and encouraged to participate. The Smithtown Central School Districts mascot is the bull. This is due to the historical significance it possesses. We are looking for a new design for the bull logo/mascot. All designs will be submitted to the Logo Committee, which will determine the next steps of the contest. All participants are eligible for prizes which are... Click Here to View

div.div: Prior to the closing of schools, the fifth graders at Tackan Elementary School learned teambuilding and technology skills during their Project Lead the Way lessons. Using Vex kits and working in small groups, students built a test bed for their robots during a unit on robotics and automation. The students learned through research about robotics and how the world is helped by robots. They were preparing to build their own simple robots by sorting and pulling parts for the test beds.

div.div:
A High School West student enlisted the help of her friends to spread kindness and smiles to frontline workers and the community during this pandemic.
Grace Kamvakis, a junior at High School West, and her mom Heidi, decided to paint rocks with inspirational thoughts on them, and leave them at the local hospitals. Grace enlisted some friends at High School West to help: Caitlin Camilleri, Olivia Bove, Goeun Chang, Carissa Philips and Jenna and Julia Savino.
After collecting and sealing the rocks from all the girls, Grace and her mom ventured out Easter morning. They graciously dropped off more than 200 rocks at the employee entryway at Huntington Hospital and St. Catherine of Sienna entryway and their serenity garden. Along with the rocks, they made inspirational signs of gratitude to all the doctors, nurses and health care workers and employees. They also included a note to take a rock and to spread positivity.
Since then, some of these rocks showing up on walking trails in the area. The girls are hoping their act will inspire more students to express random acts of kindness in the community. They have even received a call from St. Catherines asking for more for its serenity garden.

img.alt: main thumbnail168778

div.div:
Thanks to a project done in a middle school technology class by her daughter, a physical therapist who works in Smithtown Elementary School is able to share the power of learning with her own students.
Before the closing of schools, students in Mr. Kellys technology class at Great Hollow Middle School are assigned a project to create and build a toy for a child with special needs. Avery Nasta built a puzzle that her mom, Kathleen, now uses with her elementary students. The puzzle Avery created allows students to complete it while they are on their hands and knees, building strength and postural endurance.
I brought the toy to work with me, said Ms. Nasta. These students were able to use the toy, as intended, and it was an amazing thing to watch, knowing that it was made by students within the district as a project.

2 thumbnail168665

div.h3: Building Next Level Literacy Skills at Dogwood
div.div: Before the schools shut down, the fifth graders at Dogwood Elementary School were busy building their literacy skills in March. The students crafted two voice poems creating a dialogue between two main characters and depicting their relationship based on the book Esperanza Rising. Students also read Malalas Magic Pencil as a class and wrote about her identity, personality and her efforts to become the youngest person to win the Nobel Peace Prize.

div.div:
We are starting an exciting project that will be part of the district's history for years to come. All students are welcome and encouraged to participate. The Smithtown Central School Districts mascot is the bull. This is due to the historical significance it possesses. We are looking for a new design for the bull logo/mascot. All designs will be submitted to the Logo Committee, which will determine the next steps of the contest. All participants are eligible for prizes which are outlined in the link below. The newly designed bull logo will be used on athletic uniforms, school banners, school marketing items, etc.
This is a fun and creative project that students can be involved with individually, as a family or with classmates (via Google Meet, Zoom, FaceTime, etc.). YOU can be the creator of the NEW SMITHTOWN BULL!
So get involved and be part of the future of the Smithtown Central School District! Please click on the following link to review Logo Contest information and details: https://bit.ly/SCSDLogoContest

img.alt: Logo thumbnail168476

br.div:
Before school closure,Tackan third graders traveled with Kathleen Bart on a virtual tour of 12 regions of the world. Based on her book, Global Gourmet, Ms. Barts colorful poster-sized illustrations bring each region to life. Through active participation, students explored multicultural celebrations, holidays, foods, customs and traditions. This fact-filled program is a lesson in culture and a celebration of ethnic diversity.
Read Full Story >

Prior to the school closure, first grade students at Tackan Elementary School investigated the science of magnetism and performed simple experiments to discover magnetic and non-magnetic metals, magnetic fields, and the force of magnets attracting and repelling. This program, sponsored by the schools Parent-Teacher Association, gets students thinking like scientists as they make their predictions and see the results.
Read Full Story >

Kathryn Re-Yakaboski of Smithtown Central School District has been named a Distinguished Teacher of 2020 by the Harvard Club of Long Island.
This award honors middle and high school teachers who have profoundly influenced their students lives, said Dr. Judith Esterquest, Chair of the Distinguished Teacher Selection Committee. Dedicated teachers like Ms. Re-Yakaboski inspire Long Island students to excel, to become passionate about learning, and to recognize the... Read Full Story >

span.b: Towers Build STEM Skills and More

br.div: Before the schools closed last month, fifth graders in Mrs. Walsh and Mrs. Floyds class at Smithtown Elementary School completed a STEM challenge to build the highest structure using marshmallows and uncooked spaghetti. The towers could be built using any guidelines except the marshmallows could not be altered. The challenge helped the students not only with their STEM skills, but also builds teamwork and communication. Read Full Story >

Through active participation, students explored multicultural celebrations, holidays, foods, customs and traditions. This fact-filled program is a lesson in culture and a celebration of ethnic diversity.

div.div:
Kathryn Re-Yakaboski of Smithtown Central School District has been named a Distinguished Teacher of 2020 by the Harvard Club of Long Island.
This award honors middle and high school teachers who have profoundly influenced their students lives, said Dr. Judith Esterquest, Chair of the Distinguished Teacher Selection Committee. Dedicated teachers like Ms. Re-Yakaboski inspire Long Island students to excel, to become passionate about learning, and to recognize the value of hard work. These teachers devote countless hours to creating better futures for our children. Ms. Re-Yakaboski will be honored at the Harvard Club of Long Islands annual University Relations Luncheon later in the year, along with 11 other teachers from across Long Island.
After graduating with an international business degree with a concentration in Spanish from Hofstra University, Ms. Yak, as she is known by her students, was selected for a credit-training program and became a financial analyst. After realizing that life working at a large commercial bank was not her calling, she pursued a second undergraduate degree in Earth and space sciences from Stony Brook University and a graduate degree in science education from Hofstra University. She has taught in the Smithtown Central School District since graduation. Initially, she taught eighth grade general science, while for the past 13 years she has taught Regents and honors science to ninth graders.
Matthew Mullahy, a High School East alum who is now a freshman at Harvard University, described Ms. Re-Yakaboski as enthusiastic in her teaching, before adding, how she gave interested students more information to feed their curiosity and increase their appetite for further knowledge, both within earth science and beyond.
She takes a personal interest in the success of all her students, Mr. Mullahy continued, and makes extraordinary efforts to help them succeed and reach their potential.
When Jennifer Bradshaw, assistant superintendent for curriculum and instruction, learned of this award, she said, Ms. Re-Yakaboski is a true exemplar of an educator, before noting, She frequently reflects on the delivery of her lessons to her students and makes every attempt to reach all of them.
Her passion and concern for students extends beyond the Earth science curriculum, dedicating time to truly get to know each and every one of her students, Ms. Bradshaw said. She helps them with individual needs and discusses future college and career path options. Ms. Re-Yakaboski is an amazing asset to the science department and Smithtown School District overall.
At the ceremony, the Harvard Club of Long Island will announce the Distinguished Teacher of 2020 who will also receive a scholarship for a Harvard experience at the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
This years dozen Distinguished Teacher Award winners were nominated by current Harvard undergraduates and then selected by Harvard Club of Long Island board members. Prior award winners from Smithtown Schools include Bruce Kahn for math in 2005 and physics teacher Joseph Rodichok in 2017.

div.h3: Towers Build STEM Skills and More
div.div: Before the schools closed last month, fifth graders in Mrs. Walsh and Mrs. Floyds class at Smithtown Elementary School completed a STEM challenge to build the highest structure using marshmallows and uncooked spaghetti. The towers could be built using any guidelines except the marshmallows could not be altered. The challenge helped the students not only with their STEM skills, but also builds teamwork and communication.
